name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: @rummyka_ Yes it was only for English language in my day spelling was marked down. I think as long as the meaning is understood it shouldn’t be a problem…

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
Surely we should be teaching kids how to check and find out spellings on what they are not sure on? rather than test in pressured and unrealistic conditions.

Spelling tests doesn’t reflect the real world. I was taught to pass the test, and never to retain spellings long term.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
To me it felt like the teachers were saying

“We are going to test you on something you have a disability in without providing support and adjustments.”

In the real world nowadays have software to help and check spellings we’re not sure on.

tweet: I truly believe we need an overhaul (at minimum) of our school system, and I’m leaning more towards the idea of abolishing schools in their current form in the UK.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: Staff members had good intentions, but I think the more I came to understand my own neurodivergence (discovering my autism/ADHD) and worked on my internalised ableism, the more I understood the sinister impact schools had on me as a child.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
These are systemic issues, being one person in the system limited my ability to make change. I feel I have can more of an impact being critical from the outside. 

I’m also no longer complicit it maintaining a system I don’t believe in.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: I worked in education because I wanted to make a positive difference due my own negative experiences in school, but as an individual staff member I found it impossible.

tweet: Basically being middle class was the only reason I passed my GCSEs as an autistic/ADHD/ dyslexic. If I came from a working class background, then I wouldn’t be able to go to uni under this change.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
My lowest grades were at GCSE due to the ableist school I was in. When I was in educational environments that could meet my needs, I thrived. 

I did scrape Cs in maths and English, mainly because I had the privilege of extra tuition outside of school. https://t.co/SgnSsH8g0v

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
Punishing my disability at school was never going to teach me anything. 

What it taught me though was not to question ableism and to some extend I “deserved it”, which really fucked me over during the first several years out of school.

Because it’s not the reality I’ve seen.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: It’s felt like cult at times, and I realised recently that I was masking to fit in with this “cult”, and that’s when I had to check in with myself and re-evaluate my relationship with online activism spaces. Because we all know the damage masking does.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: I know that I par take in the trauma sharing and dumping online, and please mute/unfollow/block if it ever gets too much. But I think how I’m engaging with autistic twitter is changing.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: Advise I give to new people is always find the people within the community to connect with, as it’s highly unlikely you’ll get on with everyone

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock

tweet: I have autistic people I connect with away from social media, and if I’m being honest, that to me feels more like an authentic community for me.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: I haven’t faced a smear campaign as Lydia describes at the end of their thread, but I do see this happening all the time for trivial issues. I’ve always said that autistic people I meet in real life feels nothing like autistic twitter. And Lydia explains why rather well.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: @Rachel_M_Hiller @SedgewickF It may not be in the style of academic critique but people are hurting and it’s unrealistic to expect people to adhere to respectability politics when they are focussing situations that have caused significant distress.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: @Rachel_M_Hiller @SedgewickF The anger and frustration comes from decades of dehumanisation and hurt by Simon’s research and theories. It may seem like a twitter pile on by non-autistic people. I see it as a trauma response that research has contributed to. People are calling it out to prevent further harm.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: @Rachel_M_Hiller @SedgewickF It’s important to understand the history of autism research. His research has caused a lot of harm to autistic people (including me). If we want autism research to actually be beneficial to autistic people, then researchers need to listen to the community.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock

I think I need to be clear.

I’m just one neurodivergent person. 

I don’t have the answers to everything. I’m very much still learning. I always will be.

I share my thoughts in relation to neurodivergency a lot. 

We’ll never all going to agree on everything.

I shouldn’t feel this pressure, but I still do.

I’ve heard people discuss the 2 diabetes types as the ‘not as serious one’ and ‘serious one’.

I don’t see subgrouping autism into theoretical neutral terms helping.

https://t.co/fV0pccA544

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
4) It’s sold to parents using fear mongering tactics for profit (mostly) 

5) I’ve heard ABA therapists say things such as “They have no voice, we are their voice” thus denying autonomy. 

6) This dehumanising and ableist quote from the founder of ABA. https://t.co/TOYNxg3QiC

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
I have several reasons

1) It does not respect the autistic way of being, and uses 
conversion therapy to try and make us “normal”.

2) Autistics who’ve been subjected to ABA say it’s abuse

3) It centres the therapist’s agenda and rarely considers autistic needs.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
So regardless of how I responded in that environment, it would have traumatised me. 

I used to think “what if I knew back then” all the time when I discovered my neurodivergence.

But now I don’t as I feel my dreams have answered that question for me on a personal level.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
I’ve been having a lot of dreams lately about how I would have done things differently as a child if I knew I was autistic at school. 

I refused school in the dream and I still experienced the same level of trauma in the dream as I did masking the “perfect student” IRL.

We may have just seen each as the same everyone else.

There could have been many missed opportunities to connect with my fellow neurokin.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
Anyway I just wanted to make people aware of that, as I did delete some tweets that got a fair amount of attention yesterday. 

My impulse tweeting is part of my neurodivergence. This can be either positive or negative.

But if I feel it’s negative, then I may delete.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
I delete a fair amount of my tweets because of impulse posting.

Sometimes I don’t feel I’ve communicated my points well when impulse posting. 

Also sometimes I realise later on that Twitter isn’t the right place to express my in-depth thoughts (that’s why I also have a blog)

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
"App Theme - choose a new theme color for your Twitter experience that can only be seen by you."

Autistic people can only tolerate certain colours and dyslexic people often rely on coloured overlays/glasses/screens to read.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
Bookmark folders - super helpful for those of us with executive dysfunction (common among neurodivergent folk), but only if we can afford to pay? 

Many of us face systemic barriers when it comes to employment and our financial situations.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:

I have to use external apps to help with this as threads can be hard to read due to my dyslexia. This would also help other with other disabilities too.

tweet:
I need advice.

1. How do I check this is the case?

My threshold to call yourself an autism expert is

You’ve lived as every single autistic person (past/present/future) for their whole lifetime.

One thing which winds me up is the term

“Early interventions” when it comes to neurodivergencies. As if we’d die with X ‘therapy’ (which can be abusive). 

NO

Understanding and support on our terms ✅

Interventions ❌

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
@NDNeuroNews I still mask today, but I’m healing from constant masking. Masking to a point I had no identity and had no way of expressing a more authentic version of myself.  

I’m certainly have a lot more healing to do, but being open in this way is part of that process for me.

tweet:
I know a lot of followers already feel that The Lancet “profound autism” is BS.

I’d also like to add that one of the authors of the paper misdiagnosed me twice when I was 4 and 5 years old. 

These people are not experts.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
On reflection, creature is too insensitive, as after all, those who suffer from neurotypcialism are human too. 

I should have said “fascinating people” as they are people first and their neurotypicalism doesn’t define them. 

Sorry for any offence caused! 

/j /s 🤣

tweet:
All neurodivergences should be recognised in this way, otherwise we’ll still have the same problems and poor life outcomes discussed in the video below. 

If justice is the motivation, then why is dyslexia the only neurodivergence in this scheme? https://t.co/0mSPwLVehp

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: Also dyslexia isn’t the only neurodivergence. This policy automatically excludes people who are also autistic, ADHDer, dyslexic, dyspraxic, dyscalculic etc.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
Long term I’m assuming the idea is that everyone gets recognise as at primary school, which should be would be ideal. 

BUT that does not change the fact that there are still many people 11 years old + won’t benefit from this policy.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
Also why only primary schools children. What about sixth form/college? University? and the workplace? 

There are still many people out their who could benefit from a dyslexia assessment and support, but not realise they are dyslexic.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
Also if a child is suspect as being dyslexic, will they have to wait for a diagnosis before they receive support or not? 

Again, this could easily disadvantage some families who experience systematic barriers with getting a diagnosis.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:

Screening and diagnosis are not the same.

There’s rarely middle ground.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
For some of us, it’s impossible.

For others, we mask. Put on a front to seem like we’re normal, but at great emotional cost with a long term hit on our mental health.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:

I suspect it’s they believe we should socialise in a neurotypical (normal) way.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.

As an autistic adult, I fundamentally disagree with this view.🧵

British media: “Lazy bastard, stop claiming benefits and get a job”

See the problem here? You can’t win with these people.

I find it ironic that many believe there is a neurotypical deep inside each autistic person.

Because, I felt forced to hide my autistic self deep inside and put on a neurotypical front.

Deep down, there is a person who is autistic AF, there is no separate neurotypical person.

tweet:
Both on twitter and Facebook I’ve seen ableism from psychologists about autism and ADHD. 

This is why many of us don’t trust psychology. This is why many psychologist who are autistic aren’t open at work. This is why so many of us have negative experiences studying psychology.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
Both before and after diagnosis I have experience discrimination based on my neurodivergence. It’s just manifested differently. But knowing about it means I understand when I’m experience ableism and can self advocate for myself.

That wasn’t the case before.

tweet: Reading aloud to the class may not seem like a big deal to most, but when everyone laughs at you and the pressure is for you to continue is humiliating.

tweet:
English in school for me was assessing the severity of my disability in front of my peers without my consent. 

I don't think the impact this has on young dyslexics is talked about enough.  

#DyslexiaAwarenessWeek

A big question for me is consent.

Did the autistic person okay it?

If they did, fine.

If not then it’s a big no. It’s a violation of the child’s privacy/boundaries.

tweet: You have to pass your theory first before taking your practical. And if you don’t pass your practical within two years of passing your theory, you have to take the theory test again.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
In the UK you have to pass 2 test to get your licence. 

First: Theory test. Multiple choice questions about knowledge of road rules and what you’d do in common situations while driving. 

Second: Practical test. Seeing if you can you actually drive a car. https://t.co/WdWSnLVP6N

tweet:
Also, I've notice schools don't often acknowledge how tiring being neurodivergent can be. Like we may have the skills to do certain take like cook, but we don't have the energy at the end of a busy day.

Then what if we’re too low on spoons to cook? 

#edutwitter

#edutwitter

I don’t view myself as broken anymore. 

The system is broken, not neurodivergent people

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock

tweet: Knowing about my neurodivergence when I was young would've helped a lot. I knew I was different from very young; I didn't know why and consequently did not have the tools to thrive + exposed to more trauma.

tweet:
When people say

“I have a family member with autism, so I understand.”

I trust them less.

In my experience, this is often said to when they’ve misunderstood autistic people’s needs or they use it as an excuse for their ableism to avoid accountability (or both!).

That’s why it shouldn’t be in the DSM. https://t.co/DiZROVXirp

description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.

description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
Also they’ve used the AQ10 to measure autistic traits. It’s outdated and doesn’t hold up when using it with the general population. The paper linked below explains the issues with  using the AQ10 in such studies. 

https://t.co/dZjTCCTBd6

People think disabled people have it great for all the accommodations we get? 

It’s always a battle to get the bare minimum accommodations we need.

It takes a lot of time, emotional effort and with no guarantee that our needs will be met.

This has to change.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: @psychedcyclist @iLemmon Also they only employed western native speakers. My organisation was one of the few to employ teachers who weren’t white. Sadly though my non-white colleagues still had many difficulties and microaggressions in their roles.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: @psychedcyclist @iLemmon So although parents were willing and could afford to pay for the lessons (on a surface level it looks like they are just paying for a service) their motivation was often social mobility based on western standards.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: @psychedcyclist @iLemmon Sure! So my view now is that western/English speaking cultures are often seen as ‘superior’ and English fluency is often essential top jobs (was the case where I taught in HK) meaning the demand for such services comes from colonialism.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
Perhaps I experienced less bullying than I would have done otherwise?

It’s often choosing the least worst option. Mask a lot to not be bullied as much, or don’t mask and experience extreme levels of bullying. 

You can’t win being autistic in school. /2

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
I had the most autistic experience swimming today.

My eyes were stinging in the pool and I had to get out early. Nobody else had this reaction and I asked the lifeguard to check the water. 

The PH was 0.3 above normal.

Three: How the hell can a robot that barely resembles a human face teach what facial expressions mean? 

Also, the robot is creepy, and as I've said before, 4-year-old Sarah would be scared and would have run away from the robot.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: Two: It would be more helpful if research would understand how to better communicate with us with a more neutral view and learn about how we experience emotions differently from non-autistic people.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: One: It's dehumanising. Research has assumed that our emotions are deficits from day 1, with little, if any consideration that we just process them differently. Why did research feel the need to view our emotional experiences as inferior?

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
I have my own personal view on this. 

Many non-autistic people categorise us as 'Robotic' with how we communicate. They assumed that the only way we can experience emotion (aka express our emotions in the way NTs expect) is by relating to a robot telling us 'what to do'. https://t.co/KKeFLDPAaL

tweet:
One of the reasons I enjoyed Mean Girls so much growing up is that it reaffirmed to me how strange neurotypical teen culture was for me. 

I can't think of another film that had a similar impact on me personally.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
Yep. 

I wasn't subjected to ABA, but growing up in a behaviourist education system and a culture where behaviourism is deemed the norm, I had no concept of what consent was until it was too late. 

Anything that teaches you to comply (no matter what) is abuse. https://t.co/XJ1WyJqA8v

If your neurodivergent or disabled and starting university in September look into and apply for disabled students allowance (DSA)

It made a huge difference for me for both my degrees but it can take time for things to be put in place, so I’d recommend applying now.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
FYI if you're asking autistic people a question in an interview better alternatives would be

“What previous experience do you have that is relevant to the role?”

“Tell me about your career history”

Be more specific with questions. 

‘Tell me about yourself’ is too vague.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
One of my first job interviews they asked me to “tell me about yourself”

I said ”umm I have a cat” as it was to vague a question to comprehend on the spot

They looked at me like I was an idiot.

How I went undiagnosed as autistic for so long is sometimes beyond me. https://t.co/EoG2F5iY5Q

Positive renfirocment is being challenged. 

The common technique used to justify ABA and other behavioural 'interventions.' 

Autistic people describe it as traumatic. 

So why is it still being used?

How is it deemed ethical?

It sounds like you’ve taught David to perform his social interactions as a neurotypical.

This is called masking. 

Masking has negative consequences that may cause problems down the line. https://t.co/o9RaetG0FI

All I can say as somebody who has been branded as a ‘picky eater’ people’s negative attitudes only made my relationship worse with food.

Understanding and compassion is what helped me. 

Also when people backed off, that’s when my eating habits improved.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
Society relationship with food is toxic in general, but ‘picky eating’ is far from a choice for many.

Making stuff like this a quirky social media game doesn’t sit right with me.

Like that time a buzzfeed quiz infantilised anybody who had a limited diet.

Part of me thinks this goes back to the social interactions I had as a kid. 

It’s defo something I’m working through.

I keep reminding myself that it’s okay that not everybody likes me. I don’t like many people tbh so why am I placing that expectation on others?

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock

tweet:

I find that not all rejections cause RSD, but interpersonal rejections seem to for me.

Yet this person bullied me for what I now know to be my autistic traits.

Society, do autistic people a favour and don’t raise your kids to be like this. https://t.co/E5IhMXxzlC

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: If no, you then discuss how soon they will likely receive the vaccine. (4)

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
If they answer yes, you are obliged to then ask the following

1) Which Vaccine?
2) How many doses have your had?
3) Side effects*

*If the neurotypical has received two does, then the expectation is to mutually compare their side effect between their first and second dose. (3)

Ask if your fellow neurotypical has received their vaccine. (2)

Since knowing my mental health has improved, I have a better understanding of my needs, I can self-advocating and my life has IMPROVED by knowing. 

It may seem like a kind thing to not tell your child, but they will know they are different and not knowing why can be harmful.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
I only got diagnosed fairly quickly because of the privileges I have. 

However, so many autistic people don’t and they deserve better if they need a formal diagnosis.

This is one reason why self diagnosis is valid, because formal diagnosis is not accessible.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
So I ask my GP for an autism referral in early May 2019.

I ended up going privately as I needed supported attached to a diagnosis ASAP.

Today (20th April 2021) I got a letter offering me an autism assessment on the NHS for May.

Nobody should have to wait 2 years

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
These ‘Therapies’ tell us that what comes naturally to us is wrong and we will only be accepted if we act in a certain way. This, they teach us to mask our autism, as if it wasn't their.

So what are the consequences of masking?

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
Well as you can see below, their goal was to teach autistic children to inhibit their behaviour. 

So essentially masking.

Masking is when we pretend to ‘not be autistic’ as a survival strategy and trauma response. https://t.co/hp4ZbGpSdv

tweet:
If you ask me

“Do you mind *insert generic household chore here*?” 

Expect an honest answer, rather than doing the task automatically.

It’s not me being rude, it’s me answering the actual question you asked. 

How you frame the question is key.

#ActuallyAutistic

That seems backwards to me? 

We need to stop gatekeeping the smaller things. Otherwise, we are automatically excluding people who could make an important contribution.

tweet:

You're basically asking people to overcome a disability that's impossible for them.

tweet:
So on paper, I'm deemed 'educated' even though I struggle to spell basic words at times. 

To me, Christine is saying, 'Your disability means you cannot be educated.' 

The two aren't mutually exclusive, and implying so is straight-up ableism. 

#GMB

tweet:
Basically, autism is not a death sentence, accept your autistic child for who they are and help us to make this world more autistic friendly. 

#AutismAcceptance #AutismAcceptanceMonth #AutismAcceptanceWeek #AutismAcceptanceDay

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
The best piece of advice I can give is truly accepted your child for who they are and don't force them to become something they are not. 

Also, do NOT put your child in ABA therapy, Here's a link explaining why.  

https://t.co/WmFevjYXOV

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
Also, your child is not the burden. The system is. 

The system tries to force them to be something they are not.

It's vital for their happiness that your child knows you don't consider them a burden.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
However, it's not the end of the world. 

Yes, there have been hard times, but that's usually because people have not been accommodating or I'm forced to work/study in an unsuitable environment.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: Much of academia and the medical world has vilified autism. If your child is diagnosed with something painted so negatively, then it's no wonder people freak and say comments like "I grieve for the child I used to have"

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: If you're a parent and your child has received an autism diagnosis, and you don't know much about it, then it doesn't take much research to come to this conclusion.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
However, I understand why this is often said. 

This world is harder for autistic people. 

Autistic people may have less opportunities. 

Stimga about autism is still rife.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
Many parents say how they mourn and grieve for the child they used to have.

This is hard to hear as an autistic person. 

People like me existence should be mourned? 

Hell No!

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
What I came to learn is that me being my authentic self wasn't the problem. 

The world was, and the world doesn't know how to work for people like me.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
Only one thing worked for me in terms of stopping in believing these thoughts. 

Discovering I was autistic.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: I assumed I was broken and I needed to be fixed. However, this made my existence miserable.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
I discovered my autism late and before I hated myself. I was extremely self-critical and viewed myself as a failure. 

Why?

Because I couldn't live up to the world's social standards without significant effort or not at all. I was rewarded for being anybody but myself.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: I'm not saying that autism is all rainbows and smiles (far from the truth, but I have a more balanced view. Autism comes with both its positives and negatives, but I wouldn't change being autistic at all!

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
Autism is often represented as a tragedy and only a negative thing that steals your true child in the middle of the night. 

However, this is far from my reality as an autistic person. I am a happy autistic person.

Morning
-Cleanser
-Vitamin C serum 
-Moisturiser 
-SPF

 Evening
-Cleanser
-Retinol 
-Moisturiser

Also use a face mask twice a week.

Dear neurotypicals, 

After much thought, consideration and after spending 20 years masking as a neurotypical, I cannot accept your offer to make me permanently neurotypical. 

I know this will be disappointing news, but I prefer being proudly autistic. 

Regards,

Sarah

/s https://t.co/hnOPWAKh5y

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: 5) Don't get me wrong, I still fall into my old people-pleasing habits a lot of the time, but being less of a people pleaser has only been a good thing for me.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
4) This was a big part of discovering my autism in my 20s. It meant I started to stop myself from trying to please everyone. 

It’s more important to be there for the people who truly matter to me, and I'm happier for it.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: 3) Also, it meant I’d had a blind spot in realising that my people-pleasing was actually really annoyed people until it was too late.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
2) If anything, the complete opposite was true. 

It made me more vulnerable, easier for people to take advantage of people and putting everybody else needs above mine (even if it meant seriously comprises to my mental health/well-being).

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
1) People don't seek your approval for who you are. 

I think a combo of how I was brought up/not knowing about my autism made me believe that people-pleasing was the only way to live my life.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
Before I knew I was autistic, I was a people pleaser to extreme levels. I thought as long as I didn't upset anyone, then I’d be fine.

Actually, this did more harm than good

tweet:
My study investigated how sensory perception impacts autistic university student’s experiences in higher education.

Some people reported their mental health was affected by the sensory environment in their qual answers. 

I'm finding this talk fascinating! 

#AutMentalHealth

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
Sensory perception impacted autistics differently for the participants in my master’s dissertation. (in line with what is being said in the this talk). Although sound seemed to impact autistic people more than visual stimuli, the difference was not significant.

#AutMentalHealth

So from when I was young, I viewed routines as negative and started to resent them. 

#AutMentalHealth

tweet:
It's a huge issue, so this thread is a little summary of what's going on in regards to autism and females. 

If you enjoyed this thread and learnt something new, I would be grateful if you could support me on Ko-Fi

https://t.co/S6Vc1F2yi3

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: However, this problem is just not limited to women! Any gender can mask and hide their autism, but the current understanding is that this is more common in autistic women (although this idea is still challenged by some).

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: "Studies suggest that the ratio of autistic males to females ranges from 2:1 to 16:1. The most-up-to-date estimate is 3:1." My personal view is that it's likely to be a similar number, but the gender bias in diagnostic assessments still acts as a barrier for many autistic females

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
Many theories that inform practitioners does not help

E.g. The extreme male brain theory suggesting that autistic people have brains that are an extreme version of a 'Male brain'

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: So what are the consequences? Autistic girls and women are not receiving the support they need, have mental health problems because of unmet needs and struggle with the demands of everyday life without understanding why.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: However, nobody realised then that autism could present differently in girls and women. Many autistic girls learn to mask their autism by pretending to normal when they are not. Meaning that generations of autistic girls and women went and still do go undiagnosed.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: There's the common stereotype that mainly boys are autistic. This goes way back as Hans Asperger was reported to have said "no women or girls were autistic"

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet:
We need to talk about autism in girls and women today because we exist, but are often still not recognised.

A thread 🧵

#IWD2021 #InternationalWomensDay #IWD #Autism

In secondary school, I was often Criticised in every school report/parents evenings that “I didn’t ask questions in class” Well...this was why. 

Social communication is a two way street. Nobody is perfect at communication, a little more compassion would go along way. https://t.co/2tqcoPxNhz

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: @NeuroRebel It doesn't feel like a privilege for me; I see it more as a survival mechanism. I often mask when my flight or fight kicks in, so it's a response coming from feeling threatened for being my autistic self.

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: @NeuroRebel On a surface level, I can understand why some may see the ability to mask/camouflage as beneficial (I.e. faking NT social communication). For me personally, started I masked out of fear, safety and to avoid harassment. The mental health consequences are dire in the long term.

tweet: @QueerlyAutistic I’m angry about him being knighted as I believe his theories had such a negative impact on my life. Also his claims about empathy are horrifying and do not reflect my experience interacting with autistic people, but he still seems to be defending “they lack cognitive empathy.”

name: Sarah Boon #StopTheShock
description: Tweeting about my not so neurotypical life (#ActuallyAutistic-ADHD-Dyslexic). Milo’s mum 🐈‍⬛. Tea Drinker. Own views. link in bio to contact. She/Her.
tweet: @QueerlyAutistic I was misdiagnosed in 1999 when his theories were prominent and well respected. As a female, it would take another 20 years to receive the right diagnosis. During the 20 years I had a lot of traumatic situations growing up from not knowing I’m autistic.
